paragraphs.text:
%md

# Oracle Machine Learning for Python (OML4Py)

***Oracle Machine Learning for Python*** (OML4Py) makes the open source Python scripting language and environment ready for the enterprise and big data. Designed for problems involving both large and small data volumes, OML4Py integrates Python with Oracle Autonomous Database, allowing users to run Python commands and scripts for statistical, machine learning, and visualization analyses on database tables and views using Python syntax. Many familiar Python functions are overloaded that translate Python behavior into SQL for running in-database, as well as new automatic machine learning capabilities.

AutoML (Automatic Machine Learning) provides built-in data science expertise about data analytics and modeling that you can employ to build machine learning models. 

In this lab, we highlight the AutoML workflow using OML4Py:

* Automatic algorithm selection - identify the most appropriate algorithm
* Automatic feature selection - select the features (predictors) that best support that algorithm
* Automatic model tuning - tune the model using algorithm hyperparameters and the selected features
* Automatic model selection - identify the most appropriate algorithm and tune the model in a single step

Copyright (c) 2021 Oracle Corporation                             
###### [The Universal Permissive License (UPL), Version 1.0](https://oss.oracle.com/licenses/upl/)

msg.data:
Oracle Machine Learning for Python (OML4Py)

Oracle Machine Learning for Python (OML4Py) makes the open source Python scripting language and environment ready for the enterprise and big data. Designed for problems involving both large and small data volumes, OML4Py integrates Python with Oracle Autonomous Database, allowing users to run Python commands and scripts for statistical, machine learning, and visualization analyses on database tables and views using Python syntax. Many familiar Python functions are overloaded that translate Python behavior into SQL for running in-database, as well as new automatic machine learning capabilities.

AutoML (Automatic Machine Learning) provides built-in data science expertise about data analytics and modeling that you can employ to build machine learning models.

In this lab, we highlight the AutoML workflow using OML4Py:

  • Automatic algorithm selection - identify the most appropriate algorithm
  • Automatic feature selection - select the features (predictors) that best support that algorithm
  • Automatic model tuning - tune the model using algorithm hyperparameters and the selected features
  • Automatic model selection - identify the most appropriate algorithm and tune the model in a single step

Copyright (c) 2021 Oracle Corporation

The Universal Permissive License (UPL), Version 1.0

paragraphs.title: Step 1: Import the OML4Py and supporting libraries
paragraphs.text:
%md

Import the *oml* package, *Pandas* package, and *automl* module.

msg.data: Import the oml package, Pandas package, and automl module.

paragraphs.text:
%python

import pandas as pd
import oml
from oml import automl

%md
.
Use the ***oml.sync*** function to create an OML Dataframe as a proxy for the database table *WINE*.

msg.data:
.
Use the oml.sync function to create an OML Dataframe as a proxy for the database table WINE.

paragraphs.text:
%python

WINE = oml.sync(table = "WINE")
print(WINE.shape)
print(WINE.dtypes)

msg.data:
(178, 14)
alcohol                           <class 'oml.core.float.Float'>
malic_acid                        <class 'oml.core.float.Float'>
ash                               <class 'oml.core.float.Float'>
alcalinity_of_ash                 <class 'oml.core.float.Float'>
magnesium                         <class 'oml.core.float.Float'>
total_phenols                     <class 'oml.core.float.Float'>
flavanoids                        <class 'oml.core.float.Float'>
nonflavanoid_phenols              <class 'oml.core.float.Float'>
proanthocyanins                   <class 'oml.core.float.Float'>
color_intensity                   <class 'oml.core.float.Float'>
hue                               <class 'oml.core.float.Float'>
od280/od315_of_diluted_wines      <class 'oml.core.float.Float'>
proline                           <class 'oml.core.float.Float'>
target                          <class 'oml.core.string.String'>
dtype: object

paragraphs.title: Step 2: Automatic algorithm selection
paragraphs.text:
%md

Prepare the wine data set by separating predictors from the target as conventional for Python model building. This produces two new proxy objects that will be used in AutoML functions.

msg.data: Prepare the wine data set by separating predictors from the target as conventional for Python model building. This produces two new proxy objects that will be used in AutoML functions.

paragraphs.text:
%python

WINE_X_cl,WINE_y_cl = WINE.drop('target'), WINE['target']

%md
.
Use AutoML to select the top classification algorithms for predicting the WINE data target. Display the top ranked algorithms and their accuracy. SVM Gaussian is ranked first and we'll use that in subsequent AutoML function invocations.

msg.data:
.
Use AutoML to select the top classification algorithms for predicting the WINE data target. Display the top ranked algorithms and their accuracy. SVM Gaussian is ranked first and we'll use that in subsequent AutoML function invocations.

paragraphs.text:
%python

as_wine_cl = automl.AlgorithmSelection(mining_function='classification', score_metric='accuracy', parallel=2)

wine_alg_ranking_cl = as_wine_cl.select(WINE_X_cl, WINE_y_cl, k=4)

print("Ranked algorithms:\n", wine_alg_ranking_cl)

selected_wine_alg_cl = next(iter(dict(wine_alg_ranking_cl).keys()))
print("Best algorithm: ", selected_wine_alg_cl)

paragraphs.title: Step 3: Automatic feature selection
paragraphs.text:
%md

In this step, you determine the features that best support the selected algorithm. First define a *FeatureSelection* object with score metric accuracy and then invoke the ***reduce*** function and specify the desired algorithm, in this case as determined above and stored in variable *selected_wine_alg_cl*. Also specify the train and test OML DataFrame proxy objects.

The set of selected columns is returned.

msg.data:
In this step, you determine the features that best support the selected algorithm. First define a FeatureSelection object with score metric accuracy and then invoke the reduce function and specify the desired algorithm, in this case as determined above and stored in variable selected_wine_alg_cl. Also specify the train and test OML DataFrame proxy objects.

The set of selected columns is returned.

paragraphs.text:
%md
.
Define the Feature Selection object *fs_wine_cl* and invoke reduce with the selected algorithms and *WINE* proxy objects.

msg.data:
.
Define the Feature Selection object fs_wine_cl and invoke reduce with the selected algorithms and WINE proxy objects.

paragraphs.text:
%python

fs_wine_cl = automl.FeatureSelection(mining_function = 'classification', score_metric = 'accuracy', parallel=2)

selected_wine_features_cl = fs_wine_cl.reduce(selected_wine_alg_cl, WINE_X_cl, WINE_y_cl)

WINE_X_reduced_cl = WINE_X_cl[:,selected_wine_features_cl]

print("Selected columns:", WINE_X_reduced_cl.columns)
print("Number of columns:")
"{} reduced to {}".format(len(WINE_X_cl.columns), len(selected_wine_features_cl))

msg.data:
Selected columns: ['alcohol', 'ash', 'alcalinity_of_ash', 'flavanoids', 'nonflavanoid_phenols', 'color_intensity', 'hue', 'od280/od315_of_diluted_wines', 'proline']
Number of columns:
'13 reduced to 9'

paragraphs.title: Try it Yourself
paragraphs.text:
%md
Try other algorithms, such as ***svm_linear*** or ***rf*** in the first argument of the ***reduce*** function see if different columns are selected.

msg.data: Try other algorithms, such as svm_linear or rf in the first argument of the reduce function see if different columns are selected.

paragraphs.text:
%python

# Insert code here

paragraphs.title: Step 4: Automatic model tuning
paragraphs.text:
%md

At this point, you are ready to build and tune the models you want to use.

First, define a ModelTuning object for classification. Then invoke tune to produce the tuned model using the algorithm selected above and the reduced data features.

Model tuning returns a dictionary with the best model and the evaluation results of the other models tried. This also contains a list of the hyperparameter choices tried and their corresponding score.

msg.data:
At this point, you are ready to build and tune the models you want to use.

First, define a ModelTuning object for classification. Then invoke tune to produce the tuned model using the algorithm selected above and the reduced data features.

Model tuning returns a dictionary with the best model and the evaluation results of the other models tried. This also contains a list of the hyperparameter choices tried and their corresponding score.

paragraphs.text:
%md
.
Define the model tuning object *mt_wine_cl* for classification and invoke tune.

msg.data:
.
Define the model tuning object mt_wine_cl for classification and invoke tune.

paragraphs.text:
%python

mt_wine_cl = automl.ModelTuning(mining_function = 'classification', parallel=2)
mt_wine_cl.tune

results_cl = mt_wine_cl.tune(selected_wine_alg_cl, WINE_X_reduced_cl, WINE_y_cl)

tuned_model_cl = results_cl['best_model']
tuned_model_cl

paragraphs.text:
%md
.
List the hyperparameters and their values tried for the top two models, along with the corresponding model's score metric value.

msg.data:
.
List the hyperparameters and their values tried for the top two models, along with the corresponding model's score metric value.

paragraphs.text:
%python

hyper_results_cl = results_cl['all_evals']

print(*hyper_results_cl[:2], sep='\n')

msg.data:
(0.9888888888888889, {'CLAS_WEIGHTS_BALANCED': 'OFF', 'SVMS_COMPLEXITY_FACTOR': 10, 'SVMS_NUM_PIVOTS': 200, 'SVMS_STD_DEV': 2.1213203435596424})
(0.9888888888888889, {'CLAS_WEIGHTS_BALANCED': 'ON', 'SVMS_COMPLEXITY_FACTOR': 10, 'SVMS_NUM_PIVOTS': 200, 'SVMS_STD_DEV': 2.1213203435596424})

paragraphs.text:
%md
.
Users can also specify a custom search space for model building using the *param_space* argument to the ***tune*** function.

msg.data:
.
Users can also specify a custom search space for model building using the param_space argument to the tune function.

paragraphs.text:
%python

search_space={'RFOR_SAMPLING_RATIO': {'type': 'continuous', 'range': [0.05, 0.5]}, 
              'RFOR_NUM_TREES': {'type': 'discrete', 'range': [50, 55]}, 
              'TREE_IMPURITY_METRIC': {'type': 'categorical', 
              'range': ['TREE_IMPURITY_ENTROPY', 'TREE_IMPURITY_GINI']},}

at_wine2_cl = automl.ModelTuning(mining_function='classification', score_metric='f1_macro', parallel=2)

results2_cl = at_wine2_cl.tune('rf', WINE_X_cl, WINE_y_cl, param_space=search_space)

score2_cl, params2_cl = results2_cl['all_evals'][0]
"{:.2}".format(score2_cl)

tuned_model2_cl = results2_cl['best_model']
tuned_model2_cl

paragraphs.title: Step 5: Automatic model selection
paragraphs.text:
%md

Model selection automatically selects the best algorithm (using Algorithm Selection) from the set of supported algorithms, then builds, tunes, and returns the best model for your data. To use model selection, specify your data and the number of algorithms you want to tune.

msg.data: Model selection automatically selects the best algorithm (using Algorithm Selection) from the set of supported algorithms, then builds, tunes, and returns the best model for your data. To use model selection, specify your data and the number of algorithms you want to tune.

paragraphs.text:
%md
.
Define a *ModelSelection* object and invoke select for automatically building the best model on our wine data.

msg.data:
.
Define a ModelSelection object and invoke select for automatically building the best model on our wine data.

paragraphs.text:
%python

ms_wine = automl.ModelSelection(mining_function = 'classification', parallel=2)

best_model = ms_wine.select(WINE_X_cl, WINE_y_cl, k=1, cv=2)
best_model
